thread.title: Best Air Travel Advice from 7 About.com Travel Experts
thread.title_full: Best Air Travel Advice from 7 About.com Travel Experts

author: Benet Wilson
title: Best Air Travel Advice from 7 About.com Travel Experts
text:
As I do research for my air travel posts, many times I’ve found great tips and advice from the great stable of About Travel experts . I believe that these experts can be great guides as you make decisions about future travel. Below is a list of tips from seven About Travel experts.
1. Family Vacations This site is the domain of Suzanne Rowan Kelleher, who has become my best friend among About Travel experts. As a mom who travels with her own kid, I have found Suzanne’s site to be an invaluable resource for everything from trip ideas to keeping my child happy while traveling. My pick from her site is this one, “Smart Parent's Guide to Flying with Kids.” I did my own version of this, “How to be the Best Travel Parent Every Time,” but Suzanne did it better. More »
2. Budget Travel If I couldn’t write as the air travel expert, I would love to write about budget travel, since I have hundreds of tips. But alas, Mark Kahler has this one, and he does a great job with it. As someone who tries to avoid paying baggage fees at all costs, his article, “Avoid Baggage Fees - Step by Step Budget Travel Tips,” really spoke to me and my inner budget hound. And here’s my advice on what you should pack in your baggage. More »
A private first class suite on Emirates. Photo courtesy of Emirates 3. Miles and Points No surprise - I’m a girl who would prefer to sit in first or business class to coach any day. But wouldn’t we all? Miles and Points expert Zach Honig explains how travelers can redeem their miles across all classes in “Choosing Between First, Business, Premium Economy and Coach.” I haven’t done a full review of all classes, but I did look at premium economy products offered by North American and international carriers . More »
Arlene Fleming 4. Caribbean Travel With the announcement of loosened travel regulations to Cuba, there have been a lot of questions about how U.S. citizens can get to the island legally. Caribbean Travel Expert Robert Curley answers that question with his post, “How to Travel to Cuba If You Are an American.” The biggest tip is despite less restrictions, Americans will need to travel with a Cuba travel organization that has an official license from the U.S. State Department, like Insight Cuba or Central Holidays , according to Curley. More »
5. Travel Tech & Gear Travel Tech & Gear Expert David Dean speaks to me with all the toys and tools out there designed to make being on the road easier. One of the toughest things for road warriors is choosing the best suitcase for the task at hand. It’s Dean to the rescue with this article, “How to Pick the Best Suitcase for Travel.” I recommend getting a quality suitcase, but going to discount stores like TJ Maxx or Marshall’s to buy one. More »
travel.state.gov. travel.state.gov 6. Europe Travel I took the family to London and Paris for Christmas, and the Paris E xpert Courtney Traub and London Expert Laura Porter were very helpful. It’s also how I discovered great information from Europe Travel Expert James Martin, who wrote the helpful post “Travel Budgeting - Budget Your Travel to be Frugal, not Cheap.” He offers ways travelers can cut costs but still enjoy a great vacation. More »
7. Food Travel I’m a big fan of trying new foods, especially when I’m traveling. One of my airline friends told me about the iSushi app , which offers recommendations for restaurants around the world. So I was delighted to see Food Travel Expert Akila McConnell’s post, “5 Apps For Travelers With Food Restrictions,” which covers everything from vegetarian/vegan to gluten-free restaurants. More »
